FacilityName: Sunoco Partners Mktg. and Terminals LP Pittsburgh

_exec_summary.SummaryText: The Sunoco Logistics - Pittsburgh Terminal complies with the National Fire Protection Association #58 (2008 Edition) for Liquefied Petroleum Gas Storage, and it is this Facility's policy to notify the Pittsburgh Fire Department and Pittsburgh and Allegheny County LEPC via the "911" service in the event of an emergency, and follow all additional response procedures set forth in the Facility's Integrated Contingency Plan, as appropriate.  Medical emergencies will require notification of the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center - St. Margaret Hospital and VA Medical Center and associated O'hara Township Emergency Medical Services via 911.  The Facility currently maintains a trained incipient stage fire and emergency response team to respond to small or initial stages of an emergency.  The Sunoco Logistics - Pittsburgh Terminal transfers/stores refined product (regular/premium gasoline) and handles product additives, including the liquefied butane blending system (direct injection into refined product pipelines to the truck loading rack).  The Risk Management Program covers the butane blending system including the associated piping, 1 x 60,000 gallon vessel, the blending skid, sampling unit (Bartec-Benke), and the truck off-loading station product connection point.  The Facility's worst case scenario is the catastrophic failure of the blending system's 60,000 gallon liquefied (pressure) butane vessel when filled to the greatest amount allowed (fill shut-off device at 85% with an alarm at 80%) resulting in a vapor cloud explosion.  This is the recommended scenario based on the EPA Guidance Document and RMP Comp.  The Facility's alternate scenario (unlikely) resulting in a substantive release based on discussion with Texon/MCE and terminal personnel capable of off-site effects is a Boiling Liquid Expanding Vapor Explosion (BLEVE) resulting in an explosion and associated fireball.  Other alternatives considered included pump failure, liquid butane pipe failure, and a tr

uck pull-away incident.  These scenarios were considered highly unlikely and did not result in an off-site impact.

The Sunoco Logistics - Pittsburgh Terminal complies with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's Accident Prevention Rules (40 CFR Part 68) and the U.S. Department of Labor - Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Regulations (29 CFR Part 1910 .119).  The butane blending system is designed, constructed, and maintained to meet or exceed the NFPA #58 requirements for Liquefied Petroleum Gas Storage.  To this date, this Facility has never had an accident involving the butane blending system (new process) resulting in deaths, injuries, property/environmental damage, evacuations or sheltering-in-place.  In the event of an emergency involving the Pittsburgh Terminal butane blending system, it is the policy of the Facility to initially contact the Pittsburgh Fire Department and request their assistance.  The Facility maintains a trained (annually) incipient fire and emergency response team, as referenced above.  The Facility's emergency response plans are coordinated with the Pittsburgh Fire Department and the Pittsburgh and Allegheny LEPCs (Allegheny county/Pittsburgh Emergency Management Agency).  The Pittsburgh Fire Department also maintains a full hazardous material response team, is aware of the Facility's butane blending system access via Butler Street, and sources (hydrants available adjacent to the Terminal).  Sunoco Logistics - River Rouge Terminal maintains a vegetation control program to minimize plant growth within 10 feet of the system.
